Posts.Content: Hi I noticed my veins felt tight and a tender during chemo, I mentioned it at the medical unit and the nurse did say that was not uncommon at all and that other patients had mentioned, it, it wasn't in anyway as severe as your description of your issue though. I often found that the medical day unit nurses were a font of all knowledge and as you were destined to be in the chair for a few hours often called for a Dr to come to you to assess the situation  We also got lucky one day with a very handsome registrar, one lady was even trying to work out if she needed to get the nurse to have him come back to look at anything for her. Maybe worth a try with the nurses or sister in charge on MDU Take care
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi I noticed my veins felt tight and a tender during chemo, I mentioned it at the medical unit and the nurse did say that was not uncommon at all and that other patients had mentioned, it, it wasn't in anyway as severe as your description of your issue though. I often found that the medical day unit nurses were a font of all knowledge and as you were destined to be in the chair for a few hours often called for a Dr to come to you to assess the situation  We also got lucky one day with a very handsome registrar, one lady was even trying to work out if she needed to get the nurse to have him come back to look at anything for her. Maybe worth a try with the nurses or sister in charge on MDU Take care
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: If it helps I updated my profile with the treatment dates (from chemo to start of rads) and all I want for Christmas is the drain out as I now have a cracking pair of new boobs for Christmas for which I thank cancer for as they are so much nicer than those old saggies I had this time last year! My only word of warning around 'gaps' is that inevitably any period where I thought great I'll pop away that week, I wasn't able to as either something still needed an appointment Have a great Christmas xx
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Pat I find a tangle teezer is soft and gentle (it looks hard as it's plastic) the larger size sits in the palm of your hand.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer groups

Posts.Content: On Amazon they are sometimes sling bags and sometimes chest bags, single strap backpack as a search brings back a number of hits, our camera bag is a single strap but only goes on one way, you would need to check it goes the right way for you.  Happy walking
Posts.Title: Trivial I know in the grand scheme of things but....

Posts.Content: Have checked with the physio, no need to stop Pilates, make the teacher aware and stay within your limitations post surgery, I didn't realise but she actually runs a Pilates class for cancer patients near Guildford, Surrey.
Posts.Title: Pre-op nerves

Posts.Content: Hi Bonica53 My sister in law is coming for lunch tomorrow, she's a physio and Pilates instructor, I 'll see what her post op pilates advice is
Posts.Title: Pre-op nerves

Posts.Content: Loulou1007  i'm sorry to read your post, so very distressing, I would suggest ringing the Macmillan helpline and having a chat with them.  The number is  0808 808 00 00 - Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm. Big hug from here
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Loulou1007  i'm sorry to read your post, so very distressing, I would suggest ringing the Macmillan helpline and having a chat with them.  The number is  0808 808 00 00 - Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm. Big hug from here
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah I haven't experienced this with either of my ops, I would call the hospital now this morning, who to call should be on your discharge letter?  My hospital gave me about 3 options on my letters and specific numbers for out of hours They should help you Take care and hope it settles soon xx
Posts.Title: Post Drain Pain

Posts.Content: Sorry that sounded alarmist when I re-read it, I only meant call them now to get them to look at it hopefully this morning xx
Posts.Title: Post Drain Pain

Posts.Content: Hi I've been struggling to find post surgery bra to meet the BCN advised type, I think the best option I've found is a Glamourise bra (widely available on line) I'm going to try up one band and down one cup. Had exchanges with Royce, Nicola Jane and Bravissimo without success for the front fastener firm support recommended I've shared link to the Glamourise bra in the discussion bra talk There is another brand Anita that I was going to try but haven't got round to yet
Posts.Title: Post surgery bra 30F/30FF - where to find one?

Posts.Content: That made me smile and think, if someone asks you 'Did you do anything this weekend?' you did something quite out of the ordinary! Hope you're recovering well, I tried knitting and crochet after my ops, only problem I found was the yarn kept getting tangled with the tube on the drain I also made the mistake of starting to watch a film that I thought was a chick flick, but turned out to be a dire film about cancer, I always read the synopsis first now
Posts.Title: just chatting

Posts.Content: Best of luck tomorrow, I look back and think of it a bit like starting a new job and with a fair wind it won't be too bad. As already mentioned plenty of water to help your body process it and water before, good hydration helps the veins, paracetamol before the cold cap helps dull the edge of the chill, if you have a cotton headband pop that in the bag if not already there.  The nurses are always lovely and have mentironed to me many times how much they admire the patients, their family and friends.
Posts.Title: Chemo Starts Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Silvercloud thanks so much, I will searich for those Anita bras, I thought I 'd found one, Glamourise it starts at 36, technically going to be too big but, I put in another pound this week so might fit anyway. Bravissimo explained they stock front fastening because they aren't adjustable and don't last as well The lady at Nicola Jane says they are looking to extend their size range
Posts.Title: BRA talk

Posts.Content: I bought the Glamorise front fastening and took it to appoointment this week, the BCN said it was good for post surgery. The bra that starts at 36F and keeps on going  Just glad that after all of this I'm due a smaller perky pair so hopefully in 6 months time bra shopping won't be such a strain
Posts.Title: BRA talk

Posts.Content: Ladies I know there was bra chat in another discussion but wondered if we could share links in this discussion to sources for front fastening firm support bra suppliers over a G cup? My most recent Bravissimo bra pre all this malarkey was a 34G but outside that  make and model I think I have to up a cup and the general high street runs dry there! Thanks in advance
Posts.Title: BRA talk

The inner cushioned band provides incredible bust support and great shape, all without a wire. Cotton-Lycra Spandex support bands in the back provide aEitional shoulder support while gently aiding posture. Extra wide, back adjusting straps assure a great fit and total all day comfort. 40% Nylon/Polyamide, 30% Polyester, 20% Cotton, 10% Elastane Hand wash, warm. Line Dry. Do not bleach. Criss-cross cotton-Lycra support panels support shoulders while gently aiding posture. Unique cross under and over design for better uplift, separation and support. Adjustable front hooks and extra-wide plush straps. Handwash 79% Nylon, 21% Elastane. Product available in sizes: 40C, 40D, 40E, 40F, 40G, 40H, 40J, 40K, 40DD, 42C, 42D, 42E, 42F, 42G, 42H, 42J, 42K, 42DD, 44C, 44D, 44E, 44F, 44G, 44H, 44J, 44K, 44DD, 46C, 46D, 46E, 46F, 46G, 46H, 46J, 46K, 46DD, 48C, 48D, 48E, 48F, 48G, 48H, 48J, 48K, 48DD, 50C, 50D, 50E, 50F, 50G, 50H, 50J, 50K, 50DD, 52C, 52D, 52E, 52F, 52G, 52H, 52J, 52K, 52DD
Posts.Title: BRA talk

Posts.Content: http://www.nicolajane.com
Posts.Title: BRA talk

Posts.Content: www.anita.com/.../store-locator.html
Posts.Title: BRA talk

Posts.Content: I promised a nurse in the medical day until months ago that I would cross the road safely on the way home to avoid wasting the precious NHS resources that had just been pumped into my veins, so I'm always watching out for buses. At the end of the day it's us, the patients that know what our doctors have told us, so like you I have every intention of annoying my friends and family for many Christmases to come.  I try to cut the clumsy some slack, I'm sure I've said foolish things in the pressure of the moment in days gone by. Have a great Christmas, get that sherry out the mince pies on the plate, don't forget the clotted cream and good luck with your new job in January, how very exciting a new year and a new job! xxx
Posts.Title: Am I missing something???

Posts.Content: Good luck to you both  I'm on my way to an ultrasound to check out some lumps that have appeared, along with an irritation to the bottom scar and a spotty rash all accompanied by a tightness to the right breast. If that's not a peach of a Friday, annual performance review at work today, my response in that one - I survived 2016 and here I am!  Thinkkng of you both xx
Posts.Title: Firm swelling of 'breast'

Posts.Content: Something occurred to me this morning, if you've had 3 levels of nodes removed and at heightened risk of lymphodema (can't spell that for love nor money) can you have your underarm on that side waxed? I will try to ask the BCN when I see her tomorrow to check my wound but inevitably I will forget :-)  Thanks in advance everyone
Posts.Title: Underarm Waxing

Posts.Content: Hi I had a mastectomy, node clearance and reconstructio, I came home with a drain, I had some very strange sensations, no noises that I noticed but a kind of sloshing which at the time feared was going to stay, it did all subside maybe give the Macmillan line a call for a second opinion Hope the wound heals nice and quickly for you
Posts.Title: Noisy mastectomy wound

Posts.Content: Here is a link to a knitted knocker pattern :-) http://www.knittedknockers.org/make-a-knocker/
Posts.Title: 2nd chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: I had a complete body ache with the GCSF injections first time, second time I did the injections earlier in the day and it was better, however I did also take painkillers early evening and again before bed, taking a glass of water to bed along with a spare pair of painkillers for the middle of the night if needed.  Hopefully this might help, I took paracetamol but ibuprofen or co-codamol whatever's your preferred  i dislike the injections more than anything else
Posts.Title: Day 4 visit to hospital

Posts.Content: oh, the fringe in a headband, where did you find that?  Thanks
Posts.Title: 2nd chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi I'm sure you will get lot's of positive messages today, please remember that the list of side affects are a collection of what everyone experienced and not collected from one person, that's what the nurses reminded me when I went in for round 1. Have you got a bag of tricks ready to amuse yourself during treatment, book, kindle, sweets? I'm just off for bloods and clinic ahead of chemo tomorrow, must have a water and some marmite on toast ahead of both these, keeping those veins plump for them
Posts.Title: 1st session

Posts.Content: I am slightly concerned that I am being too trusting and accepting of all that the surgeon and possibly the oncologists tell me, sometimes I read things here that contradict what will be happening to me.... I'm due a mastectomy on the right hand side and all along I've been told a node clearance, I only found out I had cancer when I found an egg sized lump under my arm, maybe that's the reason for the sure fire total node clearance, although the egg is now more mini egg than egg after chemo All along, the surgeon has said that I would be able to have immediate reconstruction, despite the fact that I will be having radiotherapy afterwards, but what is the thickening of the skin risk of having the reconstruction ahead of the radiotherapy, I'm going for the implant option? The new perky lefty that is coming to match the perky righty, could I push to have the pair done together or do I just add on those extra weeks and hope it's all done by the end of the year? On a slightly shallow front, the wedding that I had already booked before this is early Feb and the months keep on rolling by and when I got the diagnosis, I did point out that I had just booked my wedding and I needed a matching pair for early 2017 (which seemed such a long way off at the time) I have my next appt with the surgeon mid July just after my chemo finishes and feel I should have gathered my thoughts by then I am triple negative hence my topsy turvy, back to front treatment Thanks in advance for any advice
Posts.Title: Am I being too trusting?
